<h1 align="center" style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">CAUTIONARY
NOTE REGARDING FORWARD-LOOKING STATEMENTS<a name="CautionaryNoteRegardingForwardloo_111536"></a></font></b></h1>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Statements in this Annual
Report on Form 10-K of MAIR Holdings, Inc. (&#147;MAIR&#148; or the &#147;Company&#148;)
under the caption &#147;Business&#148; and &#147;Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of
Financial Condition and Results of Operations&#148; and elsewhere in this report are
forward-looking and are based upon information currently available to the
Company.&#160; The Company, through its
officers, directors or employees, may also from time to time make oral forward-looking
statements.&#160; In connection with the &#147;safe
harbor&#148; provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, the
Company is hereby identifying important factors that could cause actual results
to differ materially from those contained in any forward-looking statement
made by or on behalf of the Company.&#160;
Many important factors that could cause such a difference are described
in &#147;Item 1A.&#160; Risk Factors&#148; in this
Annual Report on Form 10-K.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Undue reliance should not
be placed on the Company&#146;s forward-looking statements because the matters
they describe are subject to known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other
unpredictable factors, many of which are beyond the Company&#146;s control.&#160; The Company&#146;s forward-looking
statements are based on the information currently available and speak only as
of the date on which this report was filed with the United States Securities
and Exchange Commission (&#147;SEC&#148;).&#160; Over
time, actual results, performance or achievements will likely differ from the
anticipated results, performance or achievements that are expressed or implied
by the Company&#146;s forward-looking statements, and such differences might
be significant and materially adverse to the Company&#146;s shareholders.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">All subsequent written or
oral forward-looking statements attributable to the Company or persons
acting on the Company&#146;s behalf are expressly qualified by the factors described
above.&#160; The Company assumes no
obligation, and disclaims any obligation, to update information contained in
this Annual Report on Form 10-K, including forward-looking
statements, as a result of facts, events or circumstances after the date of
this report, except as required by law in the normal course of its public
disclosure practices.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">1</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='1',FILE='C:\Fc\1662456477_P66473CHE_2191611\15927-1-bg-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Jun 15 02:05 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<h1 align="center" style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">PART I<a name="PartI_111541"></a></font></b></h1>

<h2 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><font style="font-weight:bold;">Item 1.&#160; BUSINESS</font><a name="Item1_Business_111542"></a></font></b></h2>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">MAIR is the holding
company for Big Sky Transportation Co. (&#147;Big Sky&#148;), a regional air carrier
based in Billings, Montana.&#160; As of March
31, 2007, MAIR was also the holding company for Mesaba Aviation, Inc. (&#147;Mesaba&#148;),
a regional air carrier based in Minneapolis, Minnesota.&#160; The Company&#146;s consolidated financial
statements include the accounts of MAIR and Big Sky, as well as Mesaba until
Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy filing on October 13, 2005 (the &#147;Petition Date&#148;).&#160; All intercompany transactions and balances
have been eliminated in consolidation.&#160;
As discussed below, the accounts of Mesaba have been deconsolidated from
the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements effective as of the Petition
Date.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mesaba filed a voluntary
petition for relief under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code (the &#147;Bankruptcy
Code&#148;) in the United States Bankruptcy Court for the District of Minnesota (the
&#147;Bankruptcy Court&#148;) on the Petition Date, after which Mesaba operated its
business as a debtor-in-possession pursuant to the Bankruptcy
Code.&#160; Mesaba filed its plan of reorganization
on January 22, 2007, which provided for Mesaba to exit bankruptcy as a wholly-owned
subsidiary of Northwest Airlines, Inc. (&#147;Northwest&#148;).&#160; The plan of reorganization was approved by
the Bankruptcy Court on April 9, 2007.&#160;
On April 24, 2007, the plan of reorganization became effective and
Mesaba exited bankruptcy as a wholly-owned subsidiary of Northwest, and,
therefore, is no longer owned by MAIR.&#160;
As a result, Mesaba&#146;s financial statements for fiscal 2007 are reported
in &#147;Item 8. Financial Statements and Supplementary Data &#150; Note&nbsp;18&#148; on a
condensed basis.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Due to Mesaba&#146;s
bankruptcy and the uncertainties surrounding the nature, timing, and specifics
of the bankruptcy proceedings, MAIR deconsolidated Mesaba&#146;s financial results
effective as of the Petition Date.&#160; As a
result, Mesaba&#146;s assets and liabilities have been removed from the Company&#146;s
consolidated balance sheets as of the Petition Date and through March 31,
2007.&#160; Mesaba&#146;s results of operations
have been removed from the Company&#146;s consolidated results of operations and
cash flows since the Petition Date, but continue to be included in such
consolidated financial statements for periods prior to the Petition Date.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">MAIR has accounted for
Mesaba&#146;s financial results under the equity method of accounting since Mesaba&#146;s
bankruptcy filing on October 13, 2005.&#160;
In accordance with Accounting Principles Board (&#147;APB&#148;) Opinion No. 18, <em><i><font face="Times New Roman">The Equity
Method of Accounting for Investments in Common Stock</font></i></em><em><i><font face="Times New Roman" style="font-style:normal;">, MAIR</font></i></em>
evaluated whether its investment in Mesaba had experienced an other-than-temporary
impairment as of March 31, 2006.&#160; MAIR&#146;s
evaluation utilized a market and income approach, including a discounted cash
flow analysis.&#160; After analyzing Mesaba&#146;s
actual losses in fiscal 2006, projected losses in fiscal 2007 as it
transitioned to a Saab-only operation, Mesaba&#146;s five-year Saab
business plan and Mesaba&#146;s liabilities subject to compromise as of March 31,
2006, MAIR concluded that its remaining investment in Mesaba had experienced an
other-than-temporary impairment.&#160;
Accordingly, effective March 31, 2006, MAIR recorded an $8.9&nbsp;million
impairment charge to write off its remaining equity investment in Mesaba.&#160; The impairment charge was recorded in &#147;Impairment
and other charges&#148; in the fiscal 2006 consolidated statement of operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of March 31, 2007,
Mesaba reported a net loss of $71.3&nbsp;million.&#160; MAIR did not record any additional losses in
its consolidated financial statements due to MAIR not having any further
obligations to fund any of Mesaba&#146;s additional losses.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The provisions of
Statement of Position 90-7, <i>Financial Reporting by
Entities in Reorganization Under the Bankruptcy Code</i> (&#147;SOP&nbsp;90-7&#148;),
applied to Mesaba&#146;s financial statements while Mesaba operated under the
provisions of Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code.&#160; SOP 90-7 does not change the
application of accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of
America (&#147;GAAP&#148;) in the preparation of financial statements.&#160; However, SOP 90-7 does require that the
financial statements, for periods including and subsequent to the filing of the
Chapter 11 petition, distinguish transactions and events that are directly
associated with the reorganization from the ongoing operations of the
business.&#160; See &#147;Item 8. Financial
Statements and Supplementary Data &#150; Note 18&#148; for the condensed financial
statements of Mesaba presented in accordance with SOP 90-7 on a stand-alone
basis as of </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">2</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='2',FILE='C:\Fc\1662456477_P66473CHE_2191611\15927-1-bg-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Jun 15 02:05 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">March 31, 2007 and 2006,
and its results of operations for each of the three years in the period ended
March 31, 2007.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Since the Petition Date,
intercompany balances between MAIR and Mesaba have not been eliminated. As of
March 31, 2007 and 2006, MAIR had an intercompany payable to Mesaba of $0.8&nbsp;million
and $0.1&nbsp;million, respectively, and Mesaba had equal intercompany amounts
receivable from MAIR.&#160; During the third
quarter of fiscal 2007, MAIR received $5.5&nbsp;million in tax refunds related
to net operating loss (&#147;NOL&#148;) carryback claims for fiscal 2006 and 2005, of
which $2.9&nbsp;million was payable to Mesaba in accordance with the Company&#146;s
tax sharing agreement.&#160; During the fourth
quarter of fiscal 2007, MAIR, Mesaba and the Internal Revenue Service (&#147;IRS&#148;)
reached a settlement regarding Mesaba&#146;s accounting for per diem allowances
during fiscal years 2001 through 2004.&#160;&#160;
Under the settlement agreement MAIR agreed to pay the IRS $1.7&nbsp;million
in taxes and interest on behalf of Mesaba for adjustments to taxable income for
the reclassification of per diem amounts for fiscal years 2002 and 2003.&#160; The IRS adjustment and NOL carryback for fiscal
2004 created an additional $0.2&nbsp;million receivable from Mesaba to
MAIR.&#160; The tax return for fiscal 2005 was
amended to incorporate the IRS adjustments and resulted in a net additional
$0.2&nbsp;million receivable from Mesaba to MAIR.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As a result of the April
2007 settlement of MAIR&#146;s proof of claim in Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy proceedings,
MAIR may be responsible for certain of Mesaba&#146;s tax obligations incurred
through April 24, 2007, the effective date of Mesaba&#146;s plan of reorganization,
for those states in which MAIR and Mesaba historically filed a unitary tax
return. Although management does not believe there is any remaining exposure, under
the settlement between MAIR and Mesaba, Mesaba agreed to relinquish its right
to the $0.8&nbsp;million intercompany balance so that MAIR can use these funds
to pay any Mesaba tax obligations that taxing authorities seek to collect from
MAIR.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Operations</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky operates as a
regional air carrier based in Billings, Montana, providing scheduled passenger,
freight, express package and charter services.&#160;
As of March 31, 2007, Big Sky provided scheduled air service to 18
communities in Montana, Colorado, Idaho, Illinois, Oregon, Wyoming and
Wisconsin.&#160; Big Sky operates daily
scheduled flights providing interline and online connecting services and local
market services.&#160; Big Sky also has code-sharing
agreements with Alaska Airlines, Horizon Air, US Air and Northwest, where its
services are marketed jointly with those air carriers for connecting flights.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In April 2007, Big Sky
began operations for Delta Air Lines, Inc. (&#147;Delta&#148;) serving communities to and
from Boston, Massachusetts, as a Delta Connection carrier.&#160; As of April 8, 2007, Big Sky provided Delta
Connection service to six cities in New York, Maine and Massachusetts with a
fleet of three Beechcraft 1900D aircraft.&#160;
During the remainder of fiscal year 2008, Big Sky is scheduled to
increase this operation by adding five additional aircraft and providing service
to other similar communities.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky participates in
the Essential Air Service (&#147;EAS&#148;) program with the Department of Transportation
(&#147;DOT&#148;).&#160; The EAS program subsidizes air
carriers to provide air service to designated rural communities throughout the country
that could not otherwise economically justify that service based on their
passenger traffic.&#160; The DOT pays EAS
subsidies for each departure in a covered market. During the years ended March
31, 2007, 2006 and 2005, Big Sky recognized revenue from EAS subsidies of $7.9&nbsp;million,
$8.0&nbsp;million, and $7.3&nbsp;million, respectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Regulations</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Pursuant to Federal
aviation laws, the DOT and the Federal Aviation Administration (&#147;FAA&#148;) have
certain regulatory authority over the operations of all air carriers.&#160; The jurisdiction of the FAA extends primarily
to the safety and operational provisions of the Federal Aviation Act, while the
responsibility of the DOT involves principally the regulation of certain
economic aspects of airline operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">FAA Regulation</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky holds an air
carrier certificate issued by the FAA permitting Big Sky to conduct flight
operations in compliance with Federal Aviation Regulations, which are the same
regulatory requirements applicable to major airlines.&#160; The FAA regulations to which Big Sky is
subject are extensive and include, among other items, regulation of aircraft
maintenance and operations, equipment, ground facilities, dispatch,
communications, training, weather </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">3</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='3',FILE='C:\Fc\1662456477_P66473CHE_2191611\15927-1-bg-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Jun 15 02:05 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">observation, flight
personnel and other matters affecting air safety.&#160; To ensure compliance with its regulations,
the FAA requires airlines to obtain operating, airworthiness and other
certificates that are subject to suspension or revocation for cause.&#160; Big Sky holds all certificates necessary for
its operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under FAA regulations,
Big Sky has established, and the FAA has approved, maintenance programs for the
aircraft it operates.&#160; These programs
provide for the ongoing maintenance of Big Sky&#146;s aircraft, ranging from
frequent routine inspections to major overhauls.&#160; Big Sky&#146;s aircraft require various levels of
maintenance or &#147;checks&#148; and periodically undergo complete overhauls.&#160; Maintenance programs are monitored closely by
the FAA, with FAA representatives routinely present at the airline&#146;s
maintenance facilities.&#160; The FAA issues
Airworthiness Directives (&#147;ADs&#148;), which mandate changes to an air carrier&#146;s
maintenance program.&#160; These ADs, which
include requirements for structural modifications to certain aircraft, are
issued to ensure that the nation&#146;s transport aircraft fleet remains
airworthy.&#160; Big Sky is currently, and
expects to remain, in compliance with all applicable requirements under all ADs
and FAA approved maintenance programs.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">DOT Regulation</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky holds a
Certificate of Public Convenience and Necessity issued by the DOT under federal
aviation laws.&#160; As a certificated
carrier, Big Sky is required to file quarterly reports with the DOT, including
a report of aircraft operating expenses and related statistics.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Transportation Security Administration Regulation</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In response to the
terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, Congress enacted the Aviation and
Transportation Security Act of 2001 (the &#147;ATSA&#148;).&#160; The ATSA created the Transportation Security
Administration (the &#147;TSA&#148;) to oversee aviation and airport security.&#160; Among other security measures, the ATSA
enhanced background checks, provided for federal air marshals aboard flights,
improved flight deck security, enhanced airline crew security training,
improved training of security screening personnel and enhanced airport
perimeter security.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Railway Labor Act</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky&#146;s relations with
its labor unions are governed by the Railway Labor Act (the &#147;RLA&#148;).&#160; Comprehensive provisions are set forth in the
RLA establishing the right of airline employees to organize and bargain
collectively and imposing a duty upon air carriers and their employees to exert
every reasonable effort to make and maintain collective bargaining
agreements.&#160; The RLA contains detailed
procedures which must be exhausted before a lawful work stoppage may occur,
including a formal declaration of an impasse by the National Mediation Board.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Environmental Regulations</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky is subject to
regulation under various environmental laws and regulations, including the
Clean Air Act, the Clean Water Act and Comprehensive Environmental Response,
Compensation and Liability Act of 1980.&#160;
In addition, many state and local governments have adopted environmental
laws and regulations to which Big Sky&#146;s operations are subject.&#160; Environmental laws and regulations are administered
by numerous federal and state agencies.&#160;
Management of Big Sky believes that Big Sky is in compliance with
standards for aircraft exhaust emissions and fuel storage facilities issued by
the Environmental Protection Agency and state and local agencies.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Other Regulations</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under the Noise Control
Act of 1972 and the Aviation Safety and Noise Abatement Act of 1979, the FAA
has authority to monitor and regulate aircraft engine noise.&#160; Management of Big Sky believes that Big Sky&#146;s
aircraft comply with or are exempt from such regulations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Insurance</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company carries the
types of insurance customary in the airline industry, including coverage for
public liability, passenger liability, property damage, aircraft loss or
damage, baggage and cargo liability, war risk, directors&#146; and officers&#146;
liability and workers&#146; compensation.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky was given the
option under the ATSA to purchase certain third-party war risk liability
insurance from the United States government on an interim basis at rates that
are more favorable than those available from the private market.&#160; Big Sky has purchased this insurance from the
FAA as provided under the ATSA.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">4</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='4',FILE='C:\Fc\1662456477_P66473CHE_2191611\15927-1-bg-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Jun 15 02:05 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Competition</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The airline industry is
highly competitive as a result of the Airline Deregulation Act of 1978 (the &#147;Deregulation
Act&#148;), which generally increased competition by eliminating restrictions on
fares and route selection.&#160; The
Deregulation Act also contributed to the withdrawal of national and major
carriers from short-haul markets by allowing them to more easily obtain additional
long-haul routes, which can be served more efficiently and profitably by
larger jet aircraft.&#160; Elimination of
barriers to entry into new markets, however, also created greater potential for
competing service by other carriers operating small, fuel-efficient
aircraft on short-haul routes serving small and medium-sized
cities.&#160; Big Sky competes with other
regional airlines on most routes it serves.&#160;
Big Sky also faces competition from regional carriers offering service
to alternative hubs for connecting flights.&#160;
Other carriers, including major carriers, can at any time institute
competing service on routes served by Big Sky.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Competitive factors in
the airline industry generally include fares, frequency and dependability of
service, convenience of flight schedules, type of aircraft flown, airports
served, relationships with travel agents and efficiency and reliability of
reservations systems and ticketing services.&#160;
The compatibility of flight schedules with those of other airlines and
the ability to offer through fares and convenient inter-airline flight
connections are also important competitive factors.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Fuel</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky purchases its
fuel under arrangements with several fuel suppliers.&#160; None of these arrangements provides
protection from fluctuations in fuel prices and supply.&#160; Big Sky believes that its arrangements assure
an adequate supply of fuel for current and future operations.&#160; In fiscal 2007, Big Sky did not purchase any
fuel from Northwest.&#160; Big Sky purchased
fuel from Northwest for $1.4&nbsp;million and $1.7&nbsp;million in fiscal 2006
and 2005, respectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Fares</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky generates its
passenger revenues from passenger ticket sales through its own reservations
center, through participation in Airline Reporting Corp., a clearinghouse for
travel agencies, and through on-line e-ticketing via Big Sky&#146;s
website at www.bigskyair.com.&#160; Big Sky
has ticketing and baggage agreements with all major airlines that serve its
regions, which allow its services to be sold by those airlines.&#160; Big Sky establishes its passenger fares on a
market-by-market basis utilizing a combination of factors,
including the cost of providing the service based upon projected passenger
levels, the competitive price of alternative means of transportation (including
both air and surface) and the distance between markets.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Aircraft Maintenance</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The maintenance performed
on Big Sky&#146;s aircraft can be divided into two general categories:&#160; routine line maintenance and major
overhauls.&#160; Line maintenance consists of
routine daily and weekly scheduled maintenance checks on aircraft, including
pre-flight, daily, weekly and overnight checks and any diagnostic and
routine repairs.&#160; Big Sky employs its own
aircraft, avionics and engine maintenance staffs that perform substantially all
routine line maintenance to the aircraft and engines.&#160; Major overhauls on Big Sky&#146;s fleets,
including airframes, engines and other rotable parts, are performed internally
or at FAA authorized facilities.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Airport and Terminal Services</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky leases airport
counter, baggage and ramp space for ground services and customer services at
all of the cities it currently serves.&#160;
Big Sky contracts for ground handling services from other airlines as
needed.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">5</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='5',FILE='C:\Fc\1662456477_P66473CHE_2191611\15927-1-bg-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Jun 15 02:05 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Employees</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of March 31, 2007,
MAIR had six employees, and Big Sky employed 363 employees.&#160; Approximately 53% of Big Sky&#146;s employees are
represented by labor unions.&#160; Big Sky did
not have any official work stoppages during fiscal 2007.&#160; Big Sky&#146;s labor agreements are as follows:</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;width:100.0%;">

  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Date</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="0%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:.8%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="page-break-inside:avoid;">

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Cyclicality and Seasonality</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The airline industry
generally is subject to cyclical moves in the economy.&#160; Because both personal discretionary travel
and business travel may be expected to decline during periods of economic
weakness, the airline industry tends to experience poorer financial results
during such periods.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Seasonal factors,
primarily weather conditions and passenger demand, generally affect Big Sky&#146;s
monthly passenger boardings.&#160; Big Sky has
historically shown a higher level of passenger boardings in the July through
December period as compared with the January through June period for many of
the cities served.&#160; As a result of such factors,
Big Sky&#146;s revenues and earnings have shown a corresponding increase during the
July through December period.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Recent Developments</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In December 2006, Delta
announced that it had selected Big Sky to operate up to eight Beechcraft 1900D
aircraft for Delta between Boston and various cities in the northeast United
States.&#160; On March 12, 2007, Big Sky and
Delta executed a Hosted Prorate Agreement (&#147;HPA&#148;) governing the Boston
operation.&#160; Under the HPA, Delta is
responsible for all ticketing and reservations for flights operated by Big
Sky.&#160; Big Sky receives 100% of the
ticketing revenue for all local traffic on Big Sky flights.&#160; Big Sky receives a prorated portion of the
ticket revenue for passengers who connect through Boston to other Delta
destinations.&#160; On the same date, Big Sky
entered into an agreement with Champlain Enterprises, Inc. d/b/a CommutAir (&#147;CommutAir&#148;)
to purchase eight Beechcraft 1900D aircraft and related spare parts with
delivery scheduled during the last half of calendar 2007.&#160; Big Sky began its Boston operations in April
2007.&#160; Additionally, Big Sky was awarded
a two-year contract from the DOT to provide EAS service between Massena,
Ogdensburg and Watertown, New York to Boston, Massachusetts.&#160; This service began in April 2007, and is a
part of Big Sky&#146;s Delta operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In January 2007, Mesaba
and Northwest entered into a Stock Purchase and Reorganization Agreement (&#147;SPRA&#148;)
by which Mesaba was to exit bankruptcy as a wholly-owned operating
subsidiary of Northwest subject to the approval of Mesaba&#146;s and Northwest&#146;s
respective bankruptcy courts.&#160; Northwest&#146;s
bankruptcy court approved the SPRA on February 27, 2007.&nbsp; The Bankruptcy
Court approved Mesaba&#146;s plan of reorganization on April 9, 2007.&nbsp; Mesaba&#146;s
plan of reorganization became effective on April 24, 2007, at which time Mesaba
exited bankruptcy.&nbsp; Thus, on April 24, 2007, MAIR&#146;s ownership of Mesaba
ceased.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Available Information</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company maintains a
website at www.mairholdings.com.&#160; On its
website, free of charge, the Company makes available its Annual Report on Form
10-K and links to the SEC website for other public filings.&#160; The Company&#146;s </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">6</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='6',FILE='C:\Fc\1662456477_P66473CHE_2191611\15927-1-bg-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Jun 15 02:05 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Code of Ethics for its
Chief Executive Officer and financial officers is also available on its
website.&#160; All information is also
available in print upon written request to the Company&#146;s General Counsel at 150
South Fifth Street, Suite 1360, Minneapolis, Minnesota 55402.&#160; The Company is not including the information
contained on or available through its website as a part of, or incorporating
such information by reference into, this Annual Report on Form 10-K.</font></p>

<h2 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><font style="font-weight:bold;">Item 1A.&#160; RISK FACTORS</font><a name="Item1a_RiskFactors_111607"></a></font></b></h2>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s operations
and financial results are subject to various risks and uncertainties, some of
which are described below.&#160; The Company
could also be adversely affected by additional risks and uncertainties not
presently known or believed to be material.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Risks Related to Mesaba&#146;s
Bankruptcy</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">If the final creditors&#146; claims
allowed in Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy proceedings exceed $125&nbsp;million, MAIR will
not receive an equity distribution from Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy estate.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As a part of Mesaba&#146;s
bankruptcy plan of reorganization, Northwest allowed Mesaba a $145&nbsp;million
claim in Northwest&#146;s own bankruptcy case.&#160;
This claim was subsequently sold to The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. (&#147;Goldman
Sachs&#148;) for approximately $125&nbsp;million, and the proceeds of this sale were
used to fund the liquidating trust established to make distributions to Mesaba&#146;s
creditors.&#160; MAIR has an allowed claim of
approximately $6.2&nbsp;million in Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy estate.&#160; In addition, Northwest assigned its $7.3&nbsp;million
allowed claim in Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy to MAIR.&#160;
Therefore, MAIR could receive up to $13.5&nbsp;million in distributions
from Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy estate, and distributions for these claims will be
made pro rata with other unsecured creditors&#146; claims.&#160; Mesaba estimated the total creditors&#146; claims
in its bankruptcy case at approximately $94&nbsp;million.&#160; If this estimate proves correct, after all
creditors are paid, MAIR could receive up to an additional $31&nbsp;million for
its equity ownership of Mesaba.&#160; However,
the failure of Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy estate to settle creditors&#146; claims could
result in a larger portion of the liquidating trust being distributed to
creditors.&#160; In such event, MAIR could
receive a lower amount, or no amount at all, in distributions for its equity
ownership of Mesaba.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">If MAIR is unable to find an
alternate sublessee for Mesaba&#146;s Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky Airport facility,
MAIR may be required to accrue an additional $9.4&nbsp;million of expense
related to the bonds associated with the initial financing of the facility.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Prior to its bankruptcy,
Mesaba leased a facility at the Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International
Airport, but vacated the facility and ceased making the required lease payments
on it in November 2005.&nbsp; In 1999, MAIR unconditionally guaranteed full and
prompt payment of the ground lease and the bonds associated with the initial
financing of the facility.&nbsp; In accordance with this guaranty, MAIR has
made the required bond and ground lease payments due since November 2005.&nbsp;
In April 2006, in exchange for the bondholders forbearing acceleration of the
bonds, MAIR delivered a letter of credit to the bondholders to assure payment
of the bonds.&nbsp; Subsequently, Mesaba rejected the facilities lease
associated with the facility, but assumed and assigned the related ground lease
to MAIR.&nbsp; The Airport Board consented to the assignment of the ground
lease.&nbsp; MAIR and the bondholders are negotiating an amendment to the
original forbearance that provides for the bondholders&#146; continued forbearance
to allow MAIR a specified number of months to identify a new tenant and execute
a sublease for the property.&nbsp; As of December 31, 2005, MAIR recorded a
$4.8&nbsp;million liability with respect to the lease and guaranty, which
assumed that the facility would remain vacant for two years, during which time
MAIR would continue to make the bond and lease payments, and that thereafter
MAIR would be able to sublease the facility at a 20% discount.&nbsp; At March
31, 2007, this accrued liability totaled $3.4&nbsp;million.&nbsp; If MAIR is
unable to find an alternate sublessee for the facility, the bondholders have
the right to call the bonds, and MAIR may be required to record an additional
liability of up to $9.4&nbsp;million.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">7</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='7',FILE='C:\Fc\1662456477_P66473CHE_2191611\15927-1-bg-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Jun 15 02:05 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Risks Related to the Company&#146;s
Business and Operation</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Big Sky&#146;s success is dependent on
its ability to obtain all necessary aircraft, engines, parts and related
maintenance and support from various aircraft manufacturers and vendors.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky is dependent on
various aircraft manufacturers and other vendors to provide sufficient parts
and related maintenance and support services on a timely basis.&#160; Additionally, Big Sky relies on various
engine manufacturers for parts, repair and overhaul services and other types of
support services.&#160; The failure of
aircraft or engine manufacturers and other vendors to provide parts or related
services on a timely, cost-effective basis could materially and adversely
affect Big Sky&#146;s business, financial condition and results of operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Big Sky could incur significant
costs if it experiences difficulty finding, training and retaining employees.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky&#146;s business is
labor-intensive and requires large numbers of pilots, maintenance
technicians and other personnel.&#160; The
airline industry has from time to time experienced a shortage of qualified
personnel, specifically pilots and maintenance technicians.&#160; In addition, as is common with most airline
competitors, Big Sky has faced turnover of its employees.&#160; For example, Big Sky&#146;s pilots and maintenance
technicians may leave to work for larger airlines which generally offer higher
salaries and more extensive benefit programs than regional airlines are
financially able to offer.&#160; In addition,
Big Sky will nearly double the size of its pilot workforce in fiscal 2008 as it
expands its Boston operation with Delta.&#160;
In the event of a significant increase in the turnover of employees in
the above-mentioned positions, Big Sky would incur significantly higher
training costs than would otherwise be necessary.&#160; Big Sky cannot provide assurance that it will
be able to recruit, train and retain the qualified employees it requires to
carry out its business plan.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Big Sky could be adversely
affected by the highly competitive nature of the airline industry.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The airline industry is
highly competitive, and Big Sky competes with low-cost airlines and
regional carriers on many of its routes.&#160;
Some of these competitors are significantly larger and possess greater
resources than Big Sky.&#160; Moreover, any
new entry in the markets Big Sky serves could lessen the economic benefits Big
Sky derives from servicing these markets.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">MAIR&#146;s
ability to diversify within the airline industry may be limited by the terms of
its side letter agreement with Mesaba&#146;s pilots&#146; union.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In January 2004, MAIR
entered into a letter agreement with the Air Line Pilots Association,
International (&#147;ALPA&#148;), Mesaba&#146;s pilots&#146; union, that may limit the types of
aircraft Big Sky may fly and may place additional requirements on MAIR if it
forms or acquires any other airline subsidiary.&#160;
In December 2006, MAIR notified ALPA that MAIR terminated the letter
agreement.&#160; MAIR subsequently filed a
lawsuit in federal district court in Houston, Texas requesting a declaratory
judgment that the letter agreement contains no termination date and is,
therefore, terminable-at-will.&#160;
If MAIR does not prevail in this litigation, MAIR may not be able to
expand Big Sky or otherwise diversify MAIR&#146;s operations in the airline
industry.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Big Sky&#146;s compliance with various
regulations governing the airline industry can be costly, and Big Sky could be
harmed if it fails to comply with such regulations.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Airlines are subject to
extensive regulatory and legal requirements that involve significant compliance
costs that can result in increased costs for passengers and the airline.&#160; The FAA, DOT and TSA periodically propose
additional laws, regulations, taxes and airport rates and charges.&#160; Such measures could have the effect of
raising ticket prices, reducing revenue, increasing costs or reducing demand
for air travel.&#160; Big Sky expects to
continue incurring expenses to comply with existing and future
regulations.&#160; Moreover, if Big Sky fails
to comply with applicable regulations, it may be subject to sanctions,
including the following:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>warning letters;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>fines;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>injunctions;</p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">8</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='8',FILE='C:\Fc\1662456477_P66473CHE_2191611\15927-1-bg-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Jun 15 02:05 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>orders relating to grounding of
aircraft, inspection of aircraft, installation of new safety-related
items and removal and replacement of certain aircraft parts; or</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>criminal
prosecutions.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Future terrorist attacks, other
world events, general economic conditions and other factors beyond the Company&#146;s
control could substantially harm the Company.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The terrorist attacks of
September 11, 2001 and the prolonged unrest in the Middle East materially
affected and continue to affect the airline industry.&#160; Concerns about further terrorist attacks have
had a negative impact on air travel demand.&#160;
In addition, security procedures introduced at airports since the attacks
have increased the inconvenience of air travel, both in reality and in customer
perception, leading to further reduction in demand.&#160; Finally, the continued rise in jet fuel
prices has had an adverse economic effect on all airlines, including Big
Sky.&#160; Additional terrorist attacks, the
fear of such attacks, continued conflict in Iraq, Afghanistan or other
countries or continued increases in fuel prices could further affect the
airline industry and could cause general instability in financial markets.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Because a substantial
portion of air travel, including business travel, is discretionary, the
industry tends to experience adverse financial results during general economic
downturns.&#160; Soft economic conditions
continue to put pressure on the profitability of the industry.&#160; Any general decline in passenger traffic may
harm the Company&#146;s business.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky&#146;s operations are
also subject to delays caused by factors beyond Big Sky&#146;s control, including
air traffic congestion at airports, adverse weather conditions and increased
security measures.&#160; Such delays frustrate
passengers, reduce aircraft utilization and increase costs, all of which may
affect profitability and harm the Company&#146;s financial condition and results of
operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Big Sky is increasingly dependent
upon technology in its operations, and any failure of such technology could
adversely affect it.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky has made
investments in technology to manage its operations.&#160; In particular, the systems operations control
center, which oversees daily flight operations, is dependent on a number of
technology systems to operate effectively.&#160;
These technology systems may be vulnerable to various sources of
interruption due to events beyond Big Sky&#146;s control, including natural
disasters, terrorist attacks, computer viruses and hackers.&#160; In addition, large-scale interruption
in technology on which Big Sky depends, such as power, telecommunications or
the Internet, could substantially disrupt Big Sky&#146;s operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Any airline accident in which Big
Sky is involved could subject Big Sky to substantial liability and seriously
harm the Company&#146;s financial condition and results of operations.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">An accident involving Big
Sky aircraft could result in injuries and loss of life and, therefore, result
in significant claims from injured persons and surviving relatives.&#160; An accident could also result in substantial
property damage, loss of aircraft from service and adverse publicity for the
affected airline.&#160; The DOT requires
airlines to carry liability insurance.&#160;
Although Big Sky believes its liability insurance is in amounts and of
the type generally consistent with industry practice, substantial claims
resulting from an accident in excess of insurance coverage would harm the
Company&#146;s business and financial results.&#160;
Any resulting claims would also be costly to defend and could harm Big
Sky&#146;s reputation. &#160;Moreover, any aircraft
accident, even if fully insured or not directly involving Big Sky, could cause
a public perception that flying is less safe or reliable than other
transportation alternatives, which could harm the Company&#146;s financial condition
and results of operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Risks Related to the Company&#146;s
Stock</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Lack of
sufficient aviation-related business opportunities or lack of shareholder
support may preclude MAIR from implementing its diversification strategy.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Following Mesaba&#146;s exit
from bankruptcy as a subsidiary of Northwest, MAIR&#146;s only operating subsidiary
is Big Sky.&nbsp; Additionally, MAIR has approximately $66&nbsp;million of cash
and investments at March 31, 2007.&nbsp; MAIR has </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">9</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='9',FILE='C:\Fc\1662456477_P66473CHE_2191611\15927-1-bg-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Jun 15 02:05 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">expressed its desire to
continue to grow Big Sky&#146;s operation and seek other business opportunities
within the airline industry.&nbsp; Meanwhile, certain of MAIR&#146;s shareholders
have publicly stated their belief that MAIR should return its cash to its
shareholders.&nbsp; MAIR has been reviewing various strategic alternatives for
diversifying, and each alternative is weighed against the value of returning
cash to MAIR&#146;s shareholders.&nbsp; If MAIR is unable to identify acceptable
diversification opportunities or if it is unable to obtain shareholder support
for those opportunities it does identify, MAIR may return some or all of its
cash to its shareholders.&nbsp; In such event, MAIR may effectively be
precluded from pursuing any other strategic transactions.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Future sales of the Company&#146;s
common stock by its shareholders could depress the price of the Company&#146;s
stock.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Sales of a large number
of shares of the Company&#146;s common stock or the availability of a large number
of shares for sale could adversely affect the market price of the Company&#146;s
common stock.&#160; As of March 31, 2007, the
Company had 15,008,285 shares of common stock outstanding.&#160; Several of the Company&#146;s shareholders own
substantial blocks of the Company&#146;s common stock.&#160; Future sales of these large blocks of the
Company&#146;s common stock could substantially depress the Company&#146;s stock price.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">The Company&#146;s stock price may
continue to be volatile.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In the past two fiscal
years, the market price of the Company&#146;s common stock has ranged from a low of
$4.50 per share to a high of $10.23 per share.&#160;
Because the Company&#146;s stock is thinly traded, its market price is
sensitive and may continue to experience substantial fluctuations due to a
variety of factors, including the following:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>failure of the Company&#146;s operating
results to meet analysts&#146; or investors&#146; expectations in any quarter;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>securities analysts&#146; estimates;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>material announcements by the Company
or Big Sky&#146;s competitors;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>public sales of a substantial number
of shares of the Company&#146;s common stock;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>regulatory actions; or</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 36.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>general
market conditions.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Anti-takeover provisions of
the Company&#146;s articles of incorporation and bylaws and of Minnesota law could
discourage, delay or prevent a change in control.</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s articles of
incorporation and bylaws, along with Minnesota law, could discourage, delay or
prevent persons from acquiring or attempting to acquire the Company.&#160; The Company&#146;s articles of incorporation
authorize the board of directors, without action by the Company&#146;s shareholders,
to designate and issue preferred stock in one or more series, with such rights,
preferences and privileges as the board of directors shall determine.&#160; The Company&#146;s articles of incorporation and
bylaws also mandate a classified board of directors, which makes changing
control of the board more difficult.&#160; The
Company&#146;s bylaws grant the board of directors the authority to adopt, amend or
repeal all or any of such bylaws, subject to the power of the shareholders to
change or repeal such bylaws.&#160; The
Company&#146;s bylaws also limit who may call meetings of the Company&#146;s
shareholders.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As a public corporation,
the Company is prohibited by the Minnesota Business Corporation Act, except
under certain specified circumstances, from engaging in any merger, significant
sale of stock or assets or business combination with any shareholder or group
of shareholders who own at least 10% of the Company&#146;s common stock.</font></p>

<h2 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><font style="font-weight:bold;">Item 1B.&#160; UNRESOLVED
STAFF COMMENTS</font><a name="Item1b_UnresolvedStaffComments_111612"></a></font></b></h2>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">None.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">10</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='10',FILE='C:\Fc\1662456477_P66473CHE_2191611\15927-1-bg-03.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Jun 15 02:05 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<h2 style="font-weight:normal;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:auto;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;"><font style="font-weight:bold;">Item 2.&#160; PROPERTIES</font><a name="Item2_Properties_111551"></a></font></b></h2>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Aircraft</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Big Sky</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The following table sets
forth certain information as to Big Sky&#146;s passenger aircraft fleet as of March
31, 2007.</font></p>

  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="87" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:65.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Seating</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="87" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:65.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Single&nbsp;Flight</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="87" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:65.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Average&nbsp;Cruising</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="205" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:153.85pt;">
  <p align="left" style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Type&nbsp;of&nbsp;Aircraft</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

  </td>

  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
