<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In conjunction with the
deconsolidation of Mesaba&#146;s results following the Petition Date, the Company
reviewed all intercompany guaranties.&#160;
The Company identified liabilities of approximately $6.0 million for the
guaranty of Mesaba&#146;s Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport
facility and certain Mesaba income tax obligations payable to MAIR as the filer
of the Company&#146;s consolidated tax returns. These liabilities recorded on MAIR&#146;s
financial statements are duplicative of similar amounts included in liabilities
subject to compromise recorded in Mesaba&#146;s condensed financial statements (see
Note 18) and have been eliminated from MAIR&#146;s March 31, 2006 consolidated
financial statements.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Under guidance of SOP
90-7 and APB Opinion No. 18, the Company determined that it was probable that
the duplicative liabilities would be allowed into the claim pool by the
Bankruptcy Court.&#160; Mesaba accrued $6.0
million as reorganization items related to these duplicative liabilities.&#160; Therefore, the $40.0 million of equity in
loss of Mesaba that MAIR recognized at March 31, 2006 did not include the $6.0
million in duplicative liabilities Mesaba recorded in fiscal 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In April 2007, the
Bankruptcy Court approved a compromise for MAIR&#146;s $55.2 million damage claim
under which Mesaba allowed MAIR a claim of up to $6.2 million relating to
repayment of the guaranty of the Cincinnati hangar lease and management
fees.&#160; Additionally, pursuant to the SPA
between MAIR and Northwest, Northwest assigned </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">38</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='38',FILE='C:\JMS\105442\07-15927-1\task2197779\15927-1-bg-09.htm',USER='105442',CD='Jun 19 04:59 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">its allowed claim of $7.3
million to MAIR.&#160; Accordingly, MAIR could
receive up to $13.5 million for its claim in Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy.&#160; As of March 31, 2007, MAIR has not recorded
any of these claims in the consolidated financial statements.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">6.</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Investments</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Investments consist
principally of government, agency, corporate and municipal securities and are
classified as available-for-sale.&#160; Fair
value of investments is determined based on quoted market prices.&#160; The Company classifies investments with an
original maturity of more than 90 days that mature within one year as
short-term and greater than one year as long-term.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of March 31, 2007 and
2006, cash, cash equivalents, short-term and long-term investments totaled
$66.0 million and $110.7 million, respectively.&#160;
</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Amortized cost,
gross unrealized gains and losses and fair value of short and long-term
investments classified as securities available for sale were as follows as of
March 31, in thousands:</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;">
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="210" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:157.7pt;">
  <p style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><!-- SET mrlHTMLTableLeft --></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="51" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:38.45pt;">

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In fiscal 2006, gross
realized losses were $0.2 million as the Company incurred some losses when it
changed its investment profile focus from tax-exempt municipal securities to
taxable securities.&#160; In fiscal 2007 and
2005, the gross realized gains and losses were insignificant, as the Company
generally held the investments until maturity. </font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">7.</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Leases</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Aircraft Leases</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky</font></u></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky&#146;s airline
fleet consisted of the following aircraft held under operating leases as of
March 31, 2007:</font></p>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of March 31, 2007, Big
Sky&#146;s fleet of Metro and Beechcraft aircraft had remaining lease terms of 5 to
44 months and aggregate monthly lease payments of approximately $0.2 million.
On March 12, 2007, Big Sky entered into an agreement with CommutAir to purchase
eight Beechcraft 1900D aircraft and related spare parts with delivery scheduled
during the last half of calendar 2007. Big Sky is in the process of obtaining
financing for these aircraft. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Although Big Sky&#146;s
airline fleet operating leases contain standard return conditions, the
operating leases do not contain any other guaranteed lease residual provisions
or purchase options for which there would be a potential contingency at the
termination of the lease period.&#160; </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">39</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

2007, the aircraft operating leases for Big Sky require future minimum rental
payments as follows, in thousands:</font></p>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Consolidated rent expense
for aircraft operating leases, excluding Mesaba after its deconsolidation on
the Petition Date, was $1.8 million, $56.3 million and $102.5 million in fiscal
2007, 2006 and 2005, respectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Non-Aircraft Leases</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company leases
land, offices, hangar facilities, equipment and certain terminal facilities
under operating leases through 2019, which provide for approximate future
minimum rental payments as follows as of March 31, in thousands:</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;">

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s
consolidated rent expense for non-aircraft operating leases was approximately
$1.5 million, $1.1 million and $15.4 million in fiscal 2007, 2006 and 2005,
respectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Separately, as described
in Note 13, MAIR has guaranteed Mesaba&#146;s obligations with respect to Mesaba&#146;s
facility at the Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky International Airport.&#160; Since Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy filing, MAIR has
made the payments owed by Mesaba under the ground lease and facilities lease,
which payments total approximately $1.2 million annually.&#160; These guaranty payments are reflected in the
table above.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Capital Lease</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Future minimum
lease payments under Big Sky&#146;s capital lease for its hangar facility and the
present value of future minimum capital lease payments as of March 31, were as
follows, in thousands:</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="8" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0.375pt 0pt;width:6.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">)</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="276" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:206.95pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Present value of
  minimum lease payments</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="7" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.0pt;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="46" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:34.3pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">511</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:6.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The carrying value of the
facility under capital lease net of accumulated depreciation was $0.4 and $0.5
million at March 31, 2007 and 2006, respectively.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">40</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='40',FILE='C:\JMS\105442\07-15927-1\task2197779\15927-1-bg-09.htm',USER='105442',CD='Jun 19 04:59 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">8.</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Notes Payable and
Long-Term Debt</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Long-term debt is
recorded in other noncurrent liabilities in the consolidated balance sheet and
consists of the following as of March&nbsp;31, in thousands:</font></p>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Long-term debt maturities

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Line of Credit</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In February 2005,
Big Sky obtained a revolving line of credit in the principal amount of $250,000
from First Interstate Bank of Billings.&#160;
In March 2006, the principal amount available under the line increased
to $370,000.&#160; The line of credit charges
a variable interest rate based on the prime rate published in the <i>Wall Street Journal</i>.&#160;
At March 31, 2007, the rate was 8.25%.&#160;
The line of credit is collateralized by Big Sky&#146;s inventory, accounts
receivable and equipment and is scheduled to mature in June 2007.&#160; The balance of the line of credit was
$370,000 as of March 31, 2007 and 2006.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">9.</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Income Taxes</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s
consolidated (benefit) provision for income taxes was comprised of the
following elements for the years ended March&nbsp;31, in thousands:</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;font-family:Times New Roman;">

 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">41</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='41',FILE='C:\JMS\105442\07-15927-1\task2197779\15927-1-bg-09.htm',USER='105442',CD='Jun 19 04:59 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

tax (benefit) expense differs from the statutory tax expense as follows for the
years ended March 31, in thousands:</font></p>

tax liability was classified as follows as of March 31, in thousands:</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="7" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.0pt;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="44" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:33.15pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#151;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="7" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.0pt;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="43" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:32.35pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#151;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:6.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="378" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:283.75pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Long term</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="51" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:38.15pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(352</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0.375pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">)</font></p>
  </td>

  </td>
  <td width="8" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:6.0pt;">

  </td>

  <td width="378" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:283.75pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="44" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:33.15pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(352</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 2.25pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">)</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="7" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:5.0pt;">
  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">$</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="43" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:32.35pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#151;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:6.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">SFAS No. 109, <i>Accounting for Income Taxes</i>, requires that all available
evidence, both positive and negative, be considered to determine whether, based
on the weight of that evidence, a valuation allowance is needed.&#160; Future realization of the tax benefits of an
existing deductible temporary difference or carryforward ultimately depends on
the existence of sufficient taxable income of the appropriate character within
the carryback or carryforward periods available under the tax law.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has performed
such an analysis, and a valuation allowance has been provided against deferred
tax assets to the extent they cannot be used to offset future income arising
from the expected reversal of taxable differences.&#160; A valuation allowance of $6.9 million and
$3.6 million as of March 31, 2007 and March 31, 2006, respectively, has been
provided due to the significance of the Company&#146;s losses and significant
uncertainties of its ability to realize these assets.&#160; The Company will be required to update its
estimates of future taxable income based upon additional information management
obtains, and the Company will continue to evaluate the realizability of the
deferred tax assets on a quarterly basis.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">42</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='42',FILE='C:\JMS\105442\07-15927-1\task2197779\15927-1-bg-09.htm',USER='105442',CD='Jun 19 04:59 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Deferred income taxes
reflect the net tax effects of temporary differences between the carrying
amounts of assets and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the
amounts used for income tax purposes.&#160; At
March 31, 2007, the Company&#146;s federal deferred tax assets included $15.7
million of NOL carryforwards (excluding Mesaba&#146;s NOL carryforwards discussed
below).&#160; Of these NOL carryforwards, $3.7
million are federal NOLs related to Big Sky and are subject to Section 382 of
the Internal Revenue Code, which restricts the annual utilization of certain
NOLs incurred prior to a change in ownership.&#160;
These Big Sky NOL carryforwards expire through 2022.&#160; The remaining $12.0 million balance is for
MAIR&#146;s federal NOLs which expire in 2026 and 2027.&#160; MAIR and Big Sky also has $21.0 million in
state NOLs (excluding Mesaba&#146;s state NOL carryforwards discussed below) which
expire over the next four to twenty years. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During the fourth quarter
of fiscal 2007, the Company received verification of a final settlement with
the IRS concerning the IRS&#146; examination of the Company&#146;s income tax returns for
fiscal 2001 through 2004.&#160; As a result of
this favorable settlement, the Company reduced its income tax payable and tax
provision by $1.5 million in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2007.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As a result of the
deconsolidation of Mesaba in the third quarter of fiscal 2006, all of Mesaba&#146;s
net deferred tax assets are no longer presented in the accompanying
consolidated balance sheet at March 31, 2007 and March 31, 2006 but remain a
part of Mesaba&#146;s condensed financial statements at March 31, 2006 (see Note
18).&#160; MAIR owned 100% of Mesaba until
April 24, 2007, at which time Northwest became the sole owner of Mesaba through
Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy plan of reorganization (see Note 14).&#160; MAIR will include Mesaba in its consolidated
tax return filings as of March 31 2007.&#160;
Mesaba&#146;s short period ending April 24, 2007 will be included in MAIR&#146;s
consolidated tax return filings for the period ending March 31, 2008.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As a result of the April
2007 settlement of MAIR&#146;s proof of claim in Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy proceedings,
MAIR may be responsible for certain of Mesaba&#146;s tax obligations incurred through
April 24, 2007, the effective date of Mesaba&#146;s plan of reorganization, for
those states in which MAIR and Mesaba historically filed a unitary tax return.
Although management does not believe there is any remaining exposure, under the
settlement between MAIR and Mesaba, Mesaba agreed to relinquish its right to
the $0.8 million intercompany balance so that MAIR can use these funds to pay
any Mesaba tax obligations that taxing authorities seek to collect from MAIR.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">10.</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Shareholders&#146; Equity</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Capital Stock</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s authorized
capital stock consists of 60,000,000 shares of common stock, par value $0.01
per share, and 1,000,000 shares of undesignated preferred stock, having no
specified par value.&#160; As of March 31,
2007, there were 15,008,285 shares of common stock issued and outstanding.&#160; No shares of preferred stock have been
issued.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Holders of common stock
are entitled to one vote per share on any matter presented to shareholders for
approval.&#160; The common stock has no
special voting rights or dividend preferences.&#160;
Holders of common stock are not allowed cumulative voting and do not
possess any preemptive rights to acquire any new or additional shares of stock
of the Company.&#160; Dividends are paid if
and when declared by the Company&#146;s board of directors.&#160; In the event of a liquidation of the Company,
holders of common stock would be entitled to a pro rata distribution of any
proceeds remaining after payment to all of the Company&#146;s creditors.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s board of
directors has the authority to designate one or more series of preferred stock,
and to fix the designations, powers, preferences, rights, qualifications,
limitations and restrictions of such series.&#160;
If so designated by the board of directors, the shares of any series of
preferred stock could be senior to the common stock with respect to
distributions.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In January 2007,
MAIR and Northwest entered into the SPA under which MAIR agreed to repurchase
all of Northwest&#146;s common stock of MAIR, subject to approval by Northwest&#146;s
Bankruptcy Court.&#160; MAIR agreed to
purchase 5,657,113 shares of stock from Northwest at a purchase price of $6.25
per share, payable in two tranches.&#160;&#160; The
closing for the stock purchase occurred on March 12, 2007, at which time MAIR
paid Northwest $4.25 per share, or approximately $24 million, and Northwest
returned all of the shares to MAIR for cancellation.&#160; Northwest&#146;s Amended Warrant to purchase
additional shares of MAIR&#146;s stock was also cancelled on that date.&#160; MAIR will be required to pay to Northwest the
remaining $2.00 per share, or approximately $11.3 million, the </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">43</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='43',FILE='C:\JMS\105442\07-15927-1\task2197779\15927-1-bg-09.htm',USER='105442',CD='Jun 19 04:59 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">earlier of October
22, 2007 or the date on which MAIR receives at least $25 million in
distributions from Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy estate on account of MAIR&#146;s equity
interest in Mesaba.&#160; The remaining
payment is recorded as a liability on the balance sheet.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Stock Option Plans</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has approved
stock option plans for key employees, directors, consultants and advisors to
the Company.&nbsp; Options have been granted and are presently outstanding
under the Company&#146;s 1994 Stock Option Plan, 1996 Director Stock Option Plan and
2000 Stock Incentive Plan.&nbsp; The 2000 Stock Incentive Plan has a provision
that automatically increases the authorized shares available for grant on
September 1 of each year by the lesser of 300,000 or 1% of the then outstanding
common shares.&nbsp; Under the plans, the compensation committee of the board
of directors grants the options and determines the vesting and exercise periods
at the time of the award.&nbsp; The purchase price of the stock for
non-qualified and incentive stock options is determined at the time of the
award and is equal to the fair market value at the time of the award.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During fiscal 2007, the
adoption of SFAS 123R has resulted in additional expense in the amount of $0.3
million related to stock options.&#160; These
amounts are included in the &#147;Wages and benefits&#148; caption in the accompanying
consolidated statements of operations for the fiscal year ended March 31,
2007.&#160; SFAS 123R also requires the
benefits of tax deductions in excess of recognized compensation cost to be
reported as a financing cash flow, rather than as an operating cash flow as
required prior to SFAS 123R.&#160; As the
Company currently has no excess tax benefits related to SFAS 123R, its adoption
has not affected the Company&#146;s consolidated statement of cash flows. The impact
of adopting SFAS 123R on future results will depend on, among other things,
levels of stock options granted in the future, actual forfeiture rates and the
timing of option exercises. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Stock option
transactions for the above three plans for the three years ended March 31 were
as follows:</font></p>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
aggregate intrinsic value of options outstanding at March 31, 2007 is
calculated as the difference between the exercise price of the underlying
option and the market price of the common stock.&#160; The aggregate intrinsic value of options exercised
during fiscal 2007 and 2006 was immaterial.&#160;
The aggregate intrinsic value of options exercised during fiscal 2005
was $0.6 million.&#160; The total fair value
of options vested was $0.4 million in each of the years ended March 31, 2007,
2006 and 2005.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">44</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

  <td width="102" style="border:none;"></td>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of March 31,
2007, there were 1,685,883 shares available for grant under the Company&#146;s 2000
Stock Incentive Plan.&#160; No shares are
available&nbsp;for future grants under either the 1994 Stock Option Plan or the
1996 Director Stock&nbsp;Option Plan.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Unrecognized
Compensation</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of March 31, 2007, the Company had $0.3 million of
total unrecognized compensation cost related to non-vested stock option
compensation arrangements granted under all equity compensation plans.&#160; Total unrecognized compensation will be
adjusted for future changes in estimated forfeitures.&#160; The Company expects to recognize the cost
over a weighted average period of two years.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">11.</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Earnings (Loss) Per Share</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Basic earnings per common
share is computed by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted average number
of shares of common stock outstanding during the year.&#160; Diluted earnings per share is computed by
dividing net income (loss) by the sum of the weighted average number of shares
of common stock outstanding plus all additional common stock that would have
been outstanding if potentially dilutive common shares related to stock options
and warrants had been exercised.&#160; Stock
options and warrants with an exercise price exceeding the fair market value of
the Company&#146;s common stock at year-end are considered antidilutive and are
excluded from the calculation.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The following table
reconciles the number of shares utilized in the earnings per share calculations
for the years ended March 31, in thousands, except per share data:</font></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%" style="border-collapse:collapse;width:100.0%;">
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="69%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:69.42%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="7%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:7.52%;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">2007</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">12.</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Segment Information</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company
follows the provisions of SFAS No. 131, <i>Disclosures about Segments
of an Enterprise and Related Information</i>.&#160; SFAS No. 131 establishes annual and interim
reporting standards for an enterprise&#146;s business segments </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">45</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='45',FILE='C:\JMS\105442\07-15927-1\task2197779\15927-1-bg-09.htm',USER='105442',CD='Jun 19 04:59 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">and related
disclosures about its products, services, geographic areas and major
customers.&#160; The method for determining
what information to report is based upon the way management organizes the
operating segments within the Company for making operating decisions and
assessing financial performance.&#160;
Although Mesaba has been deconsolidated from the Company&#146;s consolidated
financial statements as of the Petition Date, the segment information presented
below continues to include Mesaba in accordance with SFAS No. 131 and related
guidance for equity-method investees.&#160;
Mesaba&#146;s results of operations after the Petition Date are included in
the &#147;Eliminations&#148; column.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Operating segment
information for Mesaba, Big Sky and MAIR were as follows, in thousands:</font></p>

  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.2%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="41%" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:41.12%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 30.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Depreciation and amortization</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">13.</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Commitments and
Contingencies</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Workforce</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Approximately 53% of Big
Sky&#146;s workforce consists of members of unions representing pilots, mechanics
and dispatchers.&#160; The CBAs for the pilots,
mechanics and dispatchers become amendable December 2009, August 2010 and
December 2009, respectively.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Benefit Plan</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky maintains a
401(k) benefit plan covering substantially all of its employees whereby Big Sky
will match 30% of employee contributions to the plan, up to 5% of each employee&#146;s
eligible earnings.&#160; Big Sky&#146;s
contribution to the plan was not significant in fiscal 2007, 2006 or 2005.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">46</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='46',FILE='C:\JMS\105442\07-15927-1\task2197779\15927-1-bg-09.htm',USER='105442',CD='Jun 19 04:59 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During fiscal 2007, MAIR
maintained a 401(k) benefit plan covering all of its employees whereby MAIR
matched 50%, 75% or 100%, depending on length of employment, of employee
contributions to the plan, up to 8% of each employee&#146;s eligible earnings.&#160; MAIR&#146;s contribution to the plan was not
significant in fiscal 2007, 2006 or 2005.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Beginning April 30, 2007,
MAIR began participating in Big Sky&#146;s 401(k) benefit plan.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Regulatory Matters</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">From time to time, Big
Sky is party to ongoing FAA proceedings arising in the ordinary course of
business.&#160; In the opinion of management,
the resolution of these matters will not have a material adverse effect on the
Company&#146;s consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Litigation</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company is a party to
ongoing legal and tax proceedings arising in the ordinary course of
business.&#160; In the opinion of management,
the resolution of these matters will not have a material adverse effect on the
Company&#146;s consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Saab Leasing Litigation</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2002, Fairbrook
Leasing, Inc., Lambert Leasing, Inc. and Swedish Aircraft MAIR AB (&#147;Saab
Leasing&#148;) filed a declaratory judgment action against Mesaba relating to 20
Saab 340A (&#147;340A&#148;) aircraft leased by Mesaba.&nbsp; In 2003, the District Court
declared that the term sheet relating to the leases for the 340A aircraft was a
binding preliminary agreement requiring Mesaba to negotiate in good faith
toward the execution of long-term agreements for each of the 340A aircraft.&nbsp;
Although Mesaba appealed this ruling, while the appeal was pending, Saab
Leasing (relying on the District Court&#146;s declaratory judgment ruling) filed a
separate action in the District Court alleging approximately $35 million in
damages for past due and future aircraft lease obligations.&nbsp; While the
damages action was pending, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit
affirmed the District Court&#146;s declaratory judgment ruling.&#160; On July 6, 2006, the District Court in the
damages action granted Mesaba&#146;s motion for partial summary judgment, ruling
that Saab Leasing is not eligible to receive damages for the majority of its
claims against Mesaba.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Because the potential
damages for the remaining claim against Mesaba are not significant, Mesaba
never established any accrual with regard to this litigation within its
condensed financial statements.&#160; Mesaba
was unable to reach a settlement with Saab Leasing within the context of Mesaba&#146;s
bankruptcy proceedings; thus, Mesaba consented to lift the automatic stay and
allow Saab Leasing to appeal the District Court&#146;s July 2006 ruling to the
Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals.&#160; Mesaba&#146;s
bankruptcy estate will now be required to fund any litigation expenses and any
amounts that may be due to Saab Leasing if the District Court&#146;s ruling is
reversed.&#160; Any such payments by Mesaba&#146;s
bankruptcy estate would ultimately reduce the distribution MAIR is entitled to
receive from the estate.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Goldman Bankruptcy Claim</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Goldman is the largest
creditor in Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy proceedings, and it holds approximately $58
million in disputed claims asserted by itself or purchased from other
creditors.&#160; All of Goldman&#146;s disputed
claims are for aircraft and equipment leases that were rejected by
Mesaba.&nbsp; Goldman has asserted that the stipulated loss provisions of the
applicable leases, under which liquidated damages are calculated, should apply
to determine the total claim amount due to Goldman.&nbsp; Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy
estate has filed for summary judgment with the Bankruptcy Court asserting that
the liquidated damages constitute unenforceable penalties.&nbsp; Mesaba&#146;s
bankruptcy trustee instead believes that the claim allowed to Goldman should
reflect actual damages suffered, which is the amount related to Goldman&#146;s claim
that is recorded in Mesaba&#146;s liabilities subject to compromise.&nbsp; Mesaba&#146;s
bankruptcy estate will be funding the litigation expenses related to the
Goldman claim and will be responsible for making a distribution to Goldman
following resolution of the claim.&nbsp; Any such payments by Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy
estate would ultimately reduce the distribution MAIR is entitled to receive
from the estate.&nbsp; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Guaranty</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Prior
to its bankruptcy, Mesaba leased a facility at the Cincinnati/Northern Kentucky
International Airport, but vacated the facility and ceased making the required
lease payments on it in November 2005.&nbsp; In 1999, MAIR unconditionally
guaranteed full and prompt payment of the ground lease and the bonds associated
with the initial financing of the facility.&nbsp; In accordance with this guaranty,
MAIR has made the required bond and ground lease payments due since November
2005.&nbsp; In April 2006, in exchange for the bondholders forbearing
acceleration of the bonds, MAIR delivered a letter of credit to the bondholders
to assure payment of the bonds.&nbsp; Subsequently, Mesaba</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">47</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='47',FILE='C:\Fc\16615128578_P66474CHE_2191462\15927-1-bg-11.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Jun 15 01:51 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">rejected
the facilities lease associated with the facility, but assumed and assigned the
related ground lease to MAIR.&nbsp; The Airport Board consented to the
assignment of the ground lease.&#160; Since
Mesaba vacated the hangar in October 2005, MAIR has been seeking other
sublessors to lease the facility.&#160; Any
rent MAIR receives from a future sublessor would offset the lease payments that
MAIR is required to make. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">MAIR and the bondholders
are negotiating an amendment to the original forbearance that provides for the
bondholders&#146; continued forbearance to allow MAIR a specified number of months
to identify a new tenant and execute a sublease for the property.&nbsp; As of
December 31, 2005, MAIR recorded a $4.8 million liability with respect to the
lease and guaranty, which assumed that the facility would remain vacant for two
years, during which time MAIR would continue to make the bond and lease
payments, and that thereafter MAIR would be able to sublease the facility at a
20% discount.&nbsp; At March 31, 2007, this accrued liability totaled $3.4
million.&nbsp; If MAIR is unable to find an alternate sublessee for the
facility, the bondholders have the right to call the bonds, and MAIR may be
required to record an additional charge and liability of up to $9.4 million. &#160;MAIR continues to reassess this reserve as
material developments occur.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The letter of credit was
issued by First Interstate Bank of Billings (&#147;UMB&#148;) and is currently fully
collateralized by MAIR&#146;s cash account held at First Interstate Bank.&nbsp;
Under the agreement with UMB, MAIR is obligated to maintain the letter of
credit until all obligations under the bonds are satisfied.&nbsp; MAIR&#146;s annual
obligations with respect to the bonds and the ground lease for the facility
total approximately $1.2 million, and those obligations will continue through
July 2029 and will increase at scheduled intervals in accordance with the terms
of the bond documents.&nbsp; The UMB agreement and the letter of credit provide
that the amount of the letter of credit will automatically decrease each July
in accordance with the redemption schedule for the bonds. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">UMB may draw on the
letter of credit upon the occurrence of an event of default under its agreement
with MAIR, including if MAIR fails to make any payment when due to UMB, if MAIR
fails to provide evidence that the letter of credit has been renewed annually
(or if MAIR fails to renew the letter of credit), if UMB receives notice from
First Interstate Bank of the bank&#146;s intent not to renew the letter of credit,
if the bonds become subject to mandatory redemption, if MAIR fails to comply
with the terms of its agreement with UMB or if MAIR commits any event of
default under its guaranty of Mesaba&#146;s bond obligations.&nbsp; The cash
supporting the letter of credit was classified as &#147;Restricted cash&#148; on the
Company&#146;s consolidated balance sheet at March 31, 2007 and 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">Other Guarantees</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In February 2005, Big Sky
obtained a revolving line of credit in the principal amount of $250,000 from
First Interstate Bank of Billings.&#160; In
March 2006, the principal amount available under the line increased to
$370,000.&#160; The line of credit charges a
variable interest rate based on the prime rate published in the <i>Wall Street Journal</i>.&#160;
At March 31, 2007, the rate was 8.25%.&#160;
The line of credit is collateralized by Big Sky&#146;s inventory, accounts
receivable and equipment and is scheduled to mature in June 2007. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Big Sky recorded $0.6
million of restricted cash in fiscal 2007 for certificates of deposit
supporting letters of credit of $0.4 million for workers&#146; compensation
insurance and $0.2 million for aircraft fuel and airport lease agreements.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In May 2007 Big Sky
established a $0.1 million certificate of deposit supporting a customs bond
required for the June 2007 service between Boston, Massachusetts and Quebec
City and Fredericton, Canada.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">48</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='48',FILE='C:\Fc\16615128578_P66474CHE_2191462\15927-1-bg-11.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Jun 15 01:51 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">MAIR Pledge for Big Sky</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In August 2006, MAIR
entered into a pledge agreement with U.S. Bank, pursuant to which MAIR pledged
$0.8 million in exchange for U.S. Bank reducing the amount of funds that it
holds back from Big Sky when credit card payments are processed.&nbsp; U.S.
Bank processes payments for Big Sky tickets made with various credit
cards.&nbsp; In the past, and consistent with industry practice, U.S. Bank held
back a specified portion of those credit card payments until the tickets had
been used.&nbsp; MAIR agreed to pledge its cash in lieu of the required hold
back, which subsequently freed up those funds for Big Sky&#146;s use.&nbsp; Under
the pledge agreement, MAIR is free to request a release of its collateral at
any time.&nbsp; Following such a request, U.S. Bank would again begin holding
back amounts from Big Sky, and MAIR&#146;s collateral would be returned 90 days
after the held back amounts total the requisite level pursuant to U.S. Bank&#146;s
credit card processing policies.&nbsp; Because MAIR has the right to request a
release of its collateral and to terminate the pledge agreement, the amount of
cash pledged is not recorded as restricted cash.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">14.</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Mesaba Plan of
Reorganization</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">On January 22, 2007,
Mesaba and Northwest entered into the SPRA, under which Northwest agreed to
allow Mesaba a $145 million claim in Northwest&#146;s bankruptcy case.&#160; In exchange, Mesaba agreed to file a plan of
reorganization under which Mesaba&#146;s existing equity would be cancelled and new
equity would be issued to Northwest, making Mesaba a wholly-owned operating
subsidiary of Northwest.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The SPRA authorized
Mesaba to monetize its $145 million claim against Northwest to provide Mesaba&#146;s
bankruptcy estate with cash to satisfy creditors&#146; claims.&#160; Mesaba&#146;s creditors&#146; committee conducted an
auction on January 29, 2007, after which Goldman Sachs and Mesaba entered into
a forward contract by which Goldman Sachs purchased the $145 million claim for
approximately $125 million.&#160; The closing
of the sale to Goldman Sachs was contingent upon Northwest&#146;s bankruptcy court
allowing the $145 million claim and upon Mesaba&#146;s plan of reorganization being
approved by its own Bankruptcy Court.&#160;
Following Northwest&#146;s bankruptcy court&#146;s February 27, 2007 order
allowing the $145 million claim and Mesaba&#146;s Bankruptcy Court&#146;s April 9, 2007
approval of Mesaba&#146;s plan of reorganization, Goldman Sachs funded the $125
million purchase price.&#160; Mesaba exited
bankruptcy on April 24, 2007, and all the outstanding stock of Mesaba is now
owned by Northwest.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The entire $125 million
purchase price from Goldman Sachs was placed in a liquidating trust, and the
proceeds from the liquidating trust will ultimately be used to satisfy Mesaba&#146;s
creditors&#146; claims.&#160; Prior to the order
approving Mesaba&#146;s plan of reorganization, MAIR worked with Mesaba&#146;s creditors&#146;
committee to resolve the majority of Mesaba&#146;s creditors&#146; claims.&#160; The two remaining significant unresolved
claims are held by Goldman and Saab and are discussed more fully in Note
13.&#160; Mesaba currently estimates that the
allowed creditors&#146; claims will total approximately $94 million, which amount
includes MAIR&#146;s $13.1 million claim.&#160; If
Mesaba&#146;s estimate is correct, Mesaba&#146;s creditors would be paid in full,
including interest, and MAIR could receive an additional $31 million for its
equity interest in Mesaba.&#160; However, in
the event the total allowed creditors&#146; claims exceed $125 million, MAIR would
not receive any distributions for its equity ownership of Mesaba.&#160; In such event, the trust assets would be
distributed pro-rata to all of Mesaba&#146;s unsecured creditors, including
MAIR.&#160; </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The trustee for Mesaba&#146;s
liquidating trust has not yet authorized payments to any creditors.&#160; While the agreement governing the trust does
provide for interim distributions to creditors, there is no assurance that the
trustee will authorize such distributions.&#160;
MAIR expects that the remaining creditors&#146; claims should be resolved in
the next nine months and that it will receive distributions for its claim and
for its equity interest by the end of fiscal 2008.&#160; </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">49</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

  <td width="6%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:6.88%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">33</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.0%;">

deductions was due to the deconsolidation of Mesaba (see Note 1).</font></p>

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="13%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:13.08%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">20,592</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="8%" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:8.62%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">20,584</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:3.18%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><hr size="1" width="160" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:120.0pt;"></div>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(1) As discussed in Note 1, MAIR deconsolidated Mesaba&#146;s financials
results under the equity method of accounting effective October 13, 2005, the
date of Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy filing.&#160; As a
result, Mesaba&#146;s results of operation have been removed from the Company&#146;s
consolidated results of operations since October 13, 2005.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(2) The sum of the
earnings (loss) per share for each of the individual quarters does not equal
earnings per share for the fiscal year due to rounding.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">51</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='51',FILE='C:\Fc\16615128578_P66474CHE_2191462\15927-1-bg-11.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Jun 15 01:51 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">17.</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Subsequent Events</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In January 2007, Mesaba
and Northwest entered into a SPRA by which Mesaba exited bankruptcy as a
wholly-owned operating subsidiary of Northwest.&nbsp; The Bankruptcy Court
approved Mesaba&#146;s plan of reorganization on April 9, 2007.&nbsp; Mesaba&#146;s plan
of reorganization became effective on April 24, 2007, at which time Mesaba
exited bankruptcy.&nbsp; Thus, on April 24, 2007, MAIR&#146;s ownership of Mesaba
ceased.&#160; See Note 14 for a discussion of
Mesaba&#146;s plan of reorganization.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">18.</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Financial Information of
Mesaba</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As discussed in Note 1,
MAIR has accounted for Mesaba&#146;s financial results under the equity method of
accounting since the Petition Date.&#160; In
accordance with APB Opinion No. 18, <em><i><font face="Times New Roman">The Equity Method of Accounting for Investments in
Common Stock</font></i></em><em><i><font face="Times New Roman" style="font-style:normal;">,
MAIR</font></i></em> evaluated whether its investment in Mesaba has
experienced an other-than-temporary impairment as of March 31, 2006.&#160; MAIR&#146;s evaluation utilized a market and
income approach, including a discounted cash flow analysis.&#160; After analyzing Mesaba&#146;s actual losses in
fiscal 2006, projected losses in fiscal 2007 as it transitioned to a Saab-only
operation, Mesaba&#146;s five-year Saab business plan and Mesaba&#146;s liabilities
subject to compromise as of March 31, 2006, MAIR concluded that its remaining
investment in Mesaba had experienced an other-than-temporary impairment.&#160; Accordingly, effective March 31, 2006, MAIR
recorded an $8.9 million impairment charge to write off its remaining equity investment
in Mesaba.&#160; The impairment charge was
recorded in &#147;Impairment and other charges&#148; in the fiscal 2006 consolidated
statement of operations.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As of March 31, 2007,
Mesaba reported a net loss of $71.3 million.&#160;
MAIR did not record any additional Mesaba equity method losses in MAIR&#146;s
consolidated financial statements because MAIR did not have any further
obligations to fund any of Mesaba&#146;s additional losses.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The following condensed
financial statements of Mesaba have been prepared in conformity with SOP 90-7,
which requires that the liabilities subject to compromise by the Bankruptcy
Court be segregated from liabilities not subject to compromise, and that all
transactions directly associated with the reorganization be identified.&#160; Liabilities subject to compromise include
prepetition unsecured claims that may be settled at amounts that differ from
those recorded in Mesaba&#146;s condensed financial statements.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The financial information
is also prepared on a going concern basis, which contemplates the realization
of assets and the liquidation of liabilities in the ordinary course of
business.&#160; However, as a result of the
bankruptcy filing, such realization of assets and liquidation of liabilities is
subject to significant uncertainty.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">MAIR has deconsolidated
Mesaba, its wholly-owned subsidiary, from the Company&#146;s March 31, 2007 and 2006
consolidated balance sheets and the consolidated statements of operations and
cash flows since Mesaba&#146;s bankruptcy filing on October 13, 2005 through March
31, 2007.&#160; All of MAIR&#146;s previously
reported consolidated balance sheets, statements of operations and cash flows
prior to October 13, 2005 continue to include Mesaba&#146;s financial position,
results of operations and cash flows.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">52</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:2.38%;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt 0pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.0%;">

Operations</font></b></p>

are included in Mesaba&#146;s results of operations for the year ended March 31,
2006 above and within the Company&#146;s consolidated results of operations prior to
deconsolidation:</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="57" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:43.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(24,809</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="6" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 2.25pt 0pt;width:4.15pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">)</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 18.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-18.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">(A)</font></b><b><font size="1" style="font-size:3.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Liabilities Subject to
Compromise</b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Liabilities subject to
compromise in Mesaba&#146;s condensed balance sheets at March 31, 2007 and March 31,
2006 refers to both secured and unsecured obligations that will be accounted
for under a plan of reorganization, including claims incurred prior to the
Petition Date.&#160; They represent the
estimated amount expected to be allowed on known or potential claims to be
resolved through the Chapter 11 bankruptcy process and remain subject to future
adjustments arising from negotiated settlements, actions of the Bankruptcy
Court, rejection of executory contracts and unexpired leases, the determination
as to the value of any collateral securing claims, proofs of claim or other
events.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Although Mesaba has
estimated the value of the claims that will be allowed by the Bankruptcy Court
at $94.4 million, the Bankruptcy Court will make the final determination
regarding what portion of the $245.7 million in total proofs of claim filed
will be deemed allowable claims (See Note 14).&#160;
The determination of how those liabilities will ultimately be treated
will not be known until the claims resolution process is complete.&#160; Mesaba worked with its creditors&#146; committee
and with MAIR to resolve as many proofs of claim as possible prior to the
confirmation of its plan of reorganization.&#160;
The proceeds from the sale of Mesaba&#146;s claim in Northwest&#146;s bankruptcy
have been placed in a liquidating trust and are being held for distribution to
Mesaba&#146;s creditors and MAIR.&#160; A
liquidating trustee has been appointed to work with the creditors&#146; committee
and with MAIR to continue to resolve any outstanding proofs of claim.&#160; As a result, the amounts of liabilities
subject to compromise may change.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Liabilities
subject to compromise at March 31, 2007 and 2006 were as follows, in thousands:</font></p>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-autospace:none;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">(B) Cumulative Effect of Change
in Accounting Principle</font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Upon adoption on April 1,
2006, in accordance with SFAS 123R, Mesaba recorded $0.5 million for the
cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle during the first quarter
of fiscal 2007 as a result of valuing stock appreciation rights under the fair
value method.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">54</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='54',FILE='C:\JMS\105442\07-15927-1\task2197779\15927-1-bg-13.htm',USER='105442',CD='Jun 19 05:01 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">

Information</b></p>
